sen.j: 福知山藩（ふくちやまはん）は、丹波国天田郡（現在の京都府福知山市内記）に存在した藩。
sen.e: The Fukuchiyama Domain was located in Amada County in the Province of Tanba (present-day Naiki, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture).
The Fukuchiyama Domain was located in Amada County in the Province of Tanba (present-day Naiki, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture).
sen.cmt: Changed province of Tamba to "Tamba province", as per term list of 8/7
sen.e: The Fukuchiyama Domain was located in Amada County in Tanba Province (present-day Naiki, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture).

sen.j: 居城は福知山城。
sen.e: The domain was based in the Fukuchiyama Castle.
The domain was based in Fukuchiyama-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: No "the" required. Also, I think it is conventional to add "jo".
sen.e: The domain was based in Fukuchiyama-jo Castle.

sen.j: 戦国時代 (日本)の天正7年（1579年）、織田信長の家臣であった明智光秀に丹波一国が与えられ、光秀は一族の明智秀満にこの地を任せた。
sen.e: During the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in 1579, when Mitsuhide AKECHI, Nobunaga ODA's vassal, was given the whole Province of Tanba, he entrusted this domain to one of the family members, Hidemitsu AKECHI.

During the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in 1579, when Mitsuhide AKECHI, Nobunaga ODA's vassal, was given the whole of Tanba province, he entrusted this domain to one of his family members, Hidemitsu AKECHI.
sen.cmt: Changed province of Tamba to "Tamba province", as per term list of 8/7
sen.e: During the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States) in 1579, when Mitsuhide AKECHI, Nobunaga ODA's vassal, was given the whole of Tanba Province, he entrusted this domain to one of his family members, Hidemitsu AKECHI.

sen.j: 天正10年（1582年）に光秀が信長に対して謀反を起こしたとき、秀満はその挙兵に賛成し、信長を本能寺に討った後は安土城を占領した。
sen.e: In 1582 when Mitsuhide raised a rebellion against Nobunaga, Hidemitsu supported Mitsuhide's military operation, and captured the Azuchi Castle after defeating Nobunaga at the Honno-ji Temple.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 1582, when Mitsuhide raised a rebellion against Nobunaga, Hidemitsu supported Mitsuhide's military operation, and captured the Azuchi Castle after defeating Nobunaga at Honno-ji Temple.
In 1582, when Mitsuhide raised a rebellion against Nobunaga, Hidemitsu supported Mitsuhide's military operation, and captured the Azuchi Castle after defeating Nobunaga at Honno-ji Temple.

sen.j: 光秀が山崎の戦いで豊臣秀吉に敗れると、秀満は安土城を放棄して有名な「湖水渡り」を行なって近江坂本城にいる光秀の妻子を刺し殺して自分も自殺した。
sen.e: However, when Mitsuhide was defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in the Battle of Yamazaki, Hidemitsu, who abandoned the Azuchi Castle, and carried out the famous "Kosui-watari" (rapid crossing of Lake Biwa), stabbed Mitsuhide's wife and children in the Sakamoto Castle in Omi, and ulltimately, killed himself.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, when Mitsuhide was defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in the Battle of Yamazaki, Hidemitsu, who abandoned the Azuchi Castle, and carried out the famous "Kosui-watari" (rapid crossing of Lake Biwa), stabbed Mitsuhide's wife and children in the Sakamoto Castle in Omi, and ulltimately, killed himself.

However, when Mitsuhide was defeated by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI in the Battle of Yamazaki, Hidemitsu, who abandoned the Azuchi-jo Castle, and carried out the famous 'Kosui-watari' (rapid crossing of Lake Biwa), stabbed Mitsuhide's wife and children in the Sakamoto-jo Castle in Omi, and ultimately, killed himself.
sen.cmt: -jo補足原文の「」に合わせ"を'にスペル

sen.j: その後、丹波は秀吉の支配下となり、福知山には杉原家次、小野木重次（公郷）らが入る。
sen.e: Then, the Province of Tanba was under the rule of Hideyoshi, and Ietsugu SUGIHARA and Shigetsugu ONOGI (Court Noble) entered Fukuchiyama.
The Province of Tanba was then under the control of Hideyoshi, and Ietsugu SUGIHARA and Shigetsugu ONOGI (Court Noble) took over Fukuchiyama.
sen.cmt: I think "control" is better than "rule". Also, I think "took over" is better than "enter" which doesn't really express the nuance of "took control of".
sen.e: Tanba Province was then under the control of Hideyoshi, and Ietsugu SUGIHARA and Shigetsugu ONOGI (Court Noble) took over Fukuchiyama.

sen.j: 重次は慶長5年（1600年）の関ヶ原の戦いにおいて西軍に味方し、丹後田辺城（舞鶴城）の城攻戦総大将となるが、本戦で西軍が壊滅すると東軍の細川忠興の追討を受けて自害した。
sen.e: Shigetsugu was on the side of the western army in the Sekigahara Battle in 1600, and became a commander in chief for conquering the Tanabe Castle in Tango (Maizuru Castle), but when the western army was completely defeated in the main battle, he was tracked down by Tadaoki HOSOKAWA of the eastern army, and killed himself.

Shigetsugu was on the side of the western army in the Sekigahara Battle in 1600, and became a commander in chief after conquering the Tanabe Castle in Tango (Maizuru Castle), but when the western army was completely defeated in the main battle, he was tracked down by Tadaoki HOSOKAWA of the eastern army, and killed himself.
sen.cmt: I think "after conquering" is more natural than "for conquering".
sen.e: Shigetsugu was on the side of the western army in the Sekigahara Battle in 1600, and became a commander in chief after conquering the Tanabe-jo Castle in Tango (Maizuru-jo Castle), but when the western army was completely defeated in the main battle, he was tracked down by Tadaoki HOSOKAWA of the eastern army, and killed himself.

sen.j: 同年末、関ヶ原で東軍に与した有馬豊氏は、本戦で後ろ揃えを務めた武功から、遠州横須賀藩3万石から福知山6万石に加増移封され、ここに福知山藩が立藩した。
sen.e: At the end of the year, as Toyouji ARIMA, who was on the side of the eastern army in the Sekigahara Battle, achieved such a distinguished military service as to perform a rear guard, he was transferred from the Yokosuka Domain in Enshu with 30,000 koku to Fukkuchiyama with an increase of 60,000 koku, which led to the establishment of the Fukuchiyama Domain.

At the end of the year, Toyouji ARIMA, who had served with distinction in the rear guard of the eastern army in the Sekigahara Battle, was transferred from the Yokosuka Domain in Enshu which had a yield of 30,000 koku to Fukkuchiyama where his income increased to 60,000 koku, and this led to the establishment of the Fukuchiyama Domain.
sen.cmt: It is not clear what "with XXX koku" means. Was this rice which the lords received from some sort of central authority, or was it the yield from the domain. Here I have asuumed the latter.
sen.e: At the end of the year, Toyouji ARIMA, who had served with distinction in the rear guard of the eastern army in the Sekigahara Battle, was transferred from the Yokosuka Domain in Enshu which had a yield of 30,000 koku to Fukuchiyama where his income increased to 60,000 koku, and this led to the establishment of the Fukuchiyama Domain.

sen.j: 慶長7年（1602年）に豊氏の父であった有馬則頼が死去すると、豊氏は父が摂津国三田藩に領していた2万石も相続することとなり、合計8万石の太守となった。
sen.e: When Toyouji's father, Noriyori ARIMA, died in 1602, Toyouji inherited the Sanda Domain in the Province of Settsu of 20,000 koku, and became a governor of 80,000 koku in total.

When Toyouji's father, Noriyori ARIMA, died in 1602, Toyouji inherited the Sanda Domain in Settsu Province which had a yield of 20,000 koku to bring the total yield of territories under his control to 80,000 koku.

When Toyouji's father, Noriyori ARIMA, died in 1602, Toyouji inherited the Sanda Domain in Settsu Province which had a yield of 20,000 koku to bring the total yield of territories under his control to 80,000 koku.

sen.j: その後、大坂の陣においても徳川方として武功を挙げたため、元和 (日本)6年（1620年）閏12月に20万石に加増の上で筑後国久留米藩に移封された。
sen.e: Then, he also achieved the distinguished military service on the side of Tokugawa in the Osaka Siege, so that he was awarded an increase of 200,000 koku in December 1620, and transferred to the Kurume Domain in the Province of Chikugo.

He went on to serve with distinction on the side of Tokugawa in the Osaka Siege, and was rewarded with a transfer to the Kurume Domain in Chikugo Province with increased income of 200,000 koku in December 1620..

He went on to serve with distinction on the side of Tokugawa in the Osaka Siege, and was rewarded with a transfer to the Kurume Domain in Chikugo Province with increased income of 200,000 koku in December 1620..

sen.j: その後は伏見奉行・小堀政一がしばらくは統治を行なう。
sen.e: After that, Masakazu KOBORI, a magistrate of Fushimi, ruled the domain for a while.
Masakazu KOBORI, a magistrate of Fushimi, then ruled the domain for a short period.
sen.cmt: "for a while" is a little too colloquial for this type of writing.
sen.e: Masakazu KOBORI, a magistrate of Fushimi, then ruled the domain for a short period.

sen.j: 元和7年（1621年）8月、丹波亀山藩から岡部長盛が5万石で入るが、寛永元年（1624年）9月に美濃国大垣藩に移される。
sen.e: In August, 1621, Nagamori OKABE entered the domain from the Kameyama Domain with 50,000 koku, but he was transferred to the Ogaki Domain in the Province of Mino in September, 1624.
In August, 1621, Nagamori OKABE came to the domain from the Kameyama Domain with 50,000 koku, but he was transferred to the Ogaki Domain in Mino Province in September, 1624.
sen.cmt: Again, the meaning of "with 50,000" koku is unclear. This requires fixing. Also changed "the Province of Mino" to "Mino Province".
sen.e: In August 1621, Nagamori OKABE came to the domain from the Kameyama Domain in Tanba Province with 50,000 koku, but he was transferred to the Ogaki Domain in Mino Province in September 1624.
sen.cmt: コンマ削除in Tanba Province補足

sen.j: 代わって摂津国中島藩から稲葉紀通が4万5700石で入るが、慶安元年（1648年）8月に改易となった。
sen.e: Norimichi INABA entered the domain with 45,700 koku from the Nakajima Domain in the Province of Settsu instead, but he received "Kaieki" (punishment by removal of samurai status and expropriation of territories) in August, 1648.

Norimichi INABA took over the domain with 45,700 koku from the Nakajima Domain in the Settsu Province, but punished by Kaieki (removal of samurai status and expropriation of territories) in August 1648.
sen.cmt: The meaning of "with 45,700 koku" is unclear.
sen.e: Norimichi INABA took over the domain with 45,700 koku from the Nakajima Domain in the Settsu Province, but was punished by Kaieki (removal of samurai status and expropriation of territories) in August 1648.
sen.cmt: 文法間違い。 “but punished by Kaieki ” -> “but was punished by Kaieki ”

sen.j: その後、半年ほどは天領となったが、慶安２年（１６４９年）２月２８日に三河国刈谷藩から松平忠房（島原藩主）が４５９００石で入る。
sen.e: After the domain became the imperial fief for six months, Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Shimabara Domain) entered the domain with 45,900 koku on 28 February 1649.
The domain became then became an imperial fief for six months, after which Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Shimabara Domain) took over with 45,900 koku on 28 February 1649.
sen.cmt: The meaning of "with 45,900 koku" is unclear.
sen.e: The domain then became an imperial fief for six months, after which Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Shimabara Domain) took over with 45,900 koku on February 28, 1649.
sen.cmt: became重複削除日付表記Province of位置移動

sen.j: しかし寛文9年（1669年）6月8日には肥前国島原藩に7万石で加増移封となった。
sen.e: However, he was transferred to the Shimabara in the Province of Bizen with an increase of 70,000 koku on 8 June 1669.
However, he was transferred to the Shimabara in the Province of Bizen with an income increased 70,000 koku on 8 June 1669.
sen.cmt: He did not get "an increase of 70,000 koku". Rather, his income was increased to 70,000 koku.
sen.e: However, he was transferred to the Shimabara in Bizen Province with an income increased 70,000 koku on June 8, 1669.

sen.j: 代わって、常陸国土浦藩から朽木稙昌が3万2000石で入り、以後、朽木氏13代の支配で藩政は安定化した。
sen.e: After Tanemasa KUTSUKI entered the domain with 32,000 koku from the Tsuchiura Domain in the Province of Hitachi, the rule of the Kutsuki family for 13 generations provided stabilization of the domain's administration.
After Tanemasa KUTSUKI took over the domain with 32,000 koku from the Tsuchiura Domain in the Hitachi Pronince, the Kutsuki family ruled for 13 generations, stabilizing the domain administration.
sen.cmt: Readability. Meaning of "with 32,000 koku" is unclear.
sen.e: After Tanemasa KUTSUKI took over the domain with 32,000 koku from the Tsuchiura Domain in Hitachi Province, the Kutsuki clan ruled for 13 generations, stabilizing the domain administration.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）7月14日の廃藩置県で福知山藩は廃藩となり、福知山県となる。
sen.e: The Fukuchiyama Domain was abolished following Haihan-chiken (the abolition of the feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) on 14 July 1871, the domain became Fukuchiyama Prefecture.
The Fukuchiyama Domain was abolished under Haihan-chiken (the abolition of the feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) on 14 July 1871, becoming Fukuchiyama Prefecture.
The Fukuchiyama Domain was abolished under Haihan-chiken (the abolition of the feudal domains and establishment of prefectures) on July 14, 1871, becoming Fukuchiyama Prefecture.

sen.j: 同年10月2日、豊岡県となり、明治9年（1876年）8月21日には京都府に編入されることとなったのである。
sen.e: On 2 October the same year, it became Toyooka Prefecture, and was incorporated into Kyoto Prefecture on 21 August 1876.
On 2 October of the same year, it became Toyooka Prefecture, before being incorporated into Kyoto Prefecture on 21 August 1876.
On October 2 of the same year, it became Toyooka Prefecture, before being incorporated into Kyoto Prefecture on August 21, 1876.

sen.j: 福知山は、藩が成立する前の戦国時代、光秀の治世の下で地子銭免除や城下町建設、近世的な福知山城の築城などが行なわれている。
sen.e: Before the domain was established, land-tax exemptions, the development of the castle town, and the construction of the early-modern Fukuchiyama Castle were carried out under the rule of Mitsuhide in Fukuchiyama.
Before Fukuchiyama was established as a domain, Mitsuhide implemented land-tax exemptions, developed the castle town, and constructed the early-modern Fukuchiyama-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: I think this sentence works better with Mitsuhide as the subject.
sen.e: Before Fukuchiyama was established as a domain, during the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States), Mitsuhide implemented land-tax exemptions, developed the castle town, and constructed the early-modern Fukuchiyama-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: the Sengoku Period (Period of Warring States)補足

sen.j: 初代藩主となった有馬豊氏は福知山城や城下町の整備を行ない、検地を行なって藩政を確立した。
sen.e: The first lord, Toyouji ARIMA, offered the fixed domain's administration by improving the Fukuchiyama Castle and the castle town as well as carrying out the land surbey.
The first lord, Toyouji ARIMA, sured up the domain administration by improving the Fukuchiyama Castle and the castle town, and implementing a land survey.
The first lord, Toyouji ARIMA, sured up the domain administration by improving the Fukuchiyama-jo Castle and the castle town, and implementing a land survey.

sen.j: 岡部氏は短期間のため、見るべき治績はない。
sen.e: The reign of the Okabe family was too short to achieve anything much.
The reign of the Okabe family was short, and there were no notable achievements during their tenure.
sen.cmt: Tone of trans1 is a little informal.
sen.e: The reign of the Okabe clan was short, and there were no notable achievements during their tenure.

sen.j: 岡部氏の後に入封した稲葉紀通は暗愚な人物で、家中や領民に対して悪政を敷くという暴君であった。
sen.e: Norimichi INABA, who entered the domain after the Okabe family, was such a fool and a tyrant as to misrule over his retainers and people.
Norimichi INABA, who took over the domain after the Okabe family was a tyrant, who ruled over his retainers and people with incompetence.
sen.cmt: Readability. Also the word "fool" is inappropriate here.
sen.e: Norimichi INABA, who took over the domain after the Okabe clan was a tyrant, who ruled over his retainers and people with incompetence.

sen.j: 慶安元年（1648年）には丹後国宮津藩主・京極高広との間に諍いを起こし、それが原因で紀通が謀反を企んでいるという風聞が流れた。
sen.e: As he had a conflict with Takahiro KYOGOKU, the lord of the Miyazu Domain in the Province of Tango, a rumor began circulating that Norimichi plotted a rebellion.
Due to conflict Norimichi had with Takahiro KYOGOKU, the lord of the Miyazu Domain in Tango province, a rumor began circulating that he was plotting a rebellion.
sen.cmt: Readability. Also, change "the Province of Tango" to "Tango province".
sen.e: Due to conflict Norimichi had with Takahiro KYOGOKU, the lord of the Miyazu Domain in Tango province, in 1648, a rumor began circulating that he was plotting a rebellion.

sen.j: わずか4万5700石、動員兵力においても1500人ほどにしか満たない紀通が謀反を起こしたところでたかが知れていたはずである。
sen.e: No matter how Norimichi raised a rebellion, he would have done nothing much because he had only 45,700 koku and a military force of less than 1,500.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If Norimichi had been raising a rebellion, it would have been very limited in its scope due to his income of 45,700 koku and military force of less than 1,500.
sen.cmt: Tone of translation 1 is rather informal.
sen.e: If Norimichi had been raising a rebellion, it would have been very limited in its scope due to his income of 45,700 koku and military force of less than 1,500.

sen.j: しかし、幕府もこの風聞を信じて近隣の諸藩に出兵を命じたため、同年8月20日、紀通は福知山城にて鉄砲自殺して果て、稲葉氏は改易となった。
sen.e: The shogunate took the rumor seriously, and ordered several neighboring domains to send troops, so that Norimichi committed suicide with a gun in the Fukuchiyama Castle on 20 August 1648, and the Inaba family received "Kaieki" (punishment by removal of samurai status and expropriation of territories).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The shogunate, however, took the rumor seriously, and ordered several neighboring domains to send troops, with the result that Norimichi committed shot himself dead in the Fukuchiyama Castle on 20 August 1648, and the Inaba family was punished by "Kaieki" (removal of samurai status and expropriation of territories).

The shogunate, however, took the rumor seriously, and ordered several neighboring domains to send troops, with the result that Norimichi committed shot himself dead in the Fukuchiyama-jo Castle on August 20, 1648, and the Inaba clan was punished by Kaieki (removal of samurai status and expropriation of territories).
sen.cmt: -jo補足日付表記family→clan原文に『』のない" "を削除

sen.j: 松平忠房は、藩内に検地を実施する。
sen.e: Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA carried out "Kenchi" (the land survey) in the domain.
Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA implemented "Kenchi" (a land survey) in the domain.
sen.cmt: Changed "the" to "a". Also, I prefer "implemented" to "carried out" here.
sen.e: Tadafusa MATSUDAIRA implemented Kenchi (a land survey) in the domain.

sen.j: これは明治時代の地租改正までに至る福知山藩の土地制度の基礎となったため、松平検地と呼ばれた。
sen.e: This formed the basis for the land system of the Fukuchiyama Domain till the land-tax reform came into force in the Meiji period; thus, it was called Matsudaira's Kenchi (the land survey).
This formed the basis for the land system of the Fukuchiyama Domain till the land-tax reform came into force in the Meiji period, and was called Matsudaira's Kenchi (the land survey).
This formed the basis for the land system of the Fukuchiyama Domain untill the land-tax reform came into force in the Meiji period, and was called Matsudaira's Kenchi (the land survey).

sen.j: なお、寛文6年（1666年）には宮津城の受け取り役を務めている。
sen.e: In addition, he was charged with the task of handing over the Miyazu Castle in 1666.
In addition, he was charged with the handing over of Miyazu-jo Castle in 1666.
sen.cmt: Readability. Also added "-jo" to the castle.
sen.e: In addition, he was charged with the handing over of Miyazu-jo Castle in 1666.

sen.j: そして朽木氏であるが、この朽木氏は朽木元綱で有名な朽木氏である。
sen.e: The Kutsuki family was famous for its family member, Mototsuna KUTSUKI.
The Kutsuki clan is famous thanks to Mototsuna KUTSUKI.
sen.cmt: It is obvious from his name that this chap is a member of the family.
sen.e: The Kutsuki clan is famous thanks to Mototsuna KUTSUKI.

sen.j: 初代藩主・朽木稙昌の父・朽木稙綱 (土浦藩主)は徳川家光のもとで御小姓番頭、奏者番を務め、常陸土浦に3万石を与えられ、譜代大名として厚遇された。
sen.e: The first lord, Tanemasa KUTSUKI's father, Uetsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain) who served as "Okosho Bangashira" (the chief of the bodyguard of the Shogun) and "Sojaban" (an official in charge of the ceremonies) under Iemitsu TOKUGAWA was given 30,000 koku in Hitachi Tsuchiura, and treated well as a fudai daimyo (a hereditary daimyo).

The first lord, Tanemasa KUTSUKI's father, Uetsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain) who served as "Okosho Bangashira" (the chief of the bodyguard of the Shogun) and "Sojaban" (an official in charge of the ceremonies) under Iemitsu TOKUGAWA was treated well as a fudai daimyo (a hereditary daimyo) with an award of 30,000 koku in Hitachi Tsuchiura.

The first lord, Tanemasa KUTSUKI's father, Uetsuna KUTSUKI (the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain) who served as Okosho Bangashira (the chief of the bodyguard of the Shogun) and Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies) under Iemitsu TOKUGAWA was treated well as a fudai daimyo (a hereditary daimyo) with an award of 30,000 koku in Hitachi Tsuchiura.

sen.j: 歴代藩主の多くはその経緯から、奏者番・御小姓番頭・寺社奉行を務めている。
sen.e: Many successive lords served as Sojaban, Okosho Bangashira, and "Jisha-bugyo" (a magistrate of temples and shrines) because of their background.
Many of the lords served as Sojaban, Okosho Bangashira, and "Jisha-bugyo" (a magistrate of temples and shrines) because of their lienage
Many of the lords served as Sojaban, Okosho Bangashira, and Jisha-bugyo (a magistrate of temples and shrines) because of their lineage
sen.cmt: スペル原文に『』のない" "を削除

sen.j: 藩財政は稙昌の頃から既に苦しく、元禄4年（1691年）には5ヵ年にわたる半知を行なっている。
sen.e: As the domain had already been in finacial difficulty since the time of Tanemasa, it started to halve its retainer's wages for five years in 1691.
Already financial difficulty under Tanemasa, in 1691 it halved its retainer's wages for five years.
Already in financial difficulty under Tanemasa, in 1691 it halved its retainer's wages for five years.

sen.j: 第5代藩主・朽木玄綱の時代には享保の大飢饉が原因で享保の強訴と呼ばれる騒動が起こり、藩内は混乱した。
sen.e: At the time of the fifth lord, Totsuna KUTSUKI, an upheaval called Kyoho's direct petition due to the Great Famine of Kyoho occurred, and the domain fell into confusion.
Under the fifth lord, Totsuna KUTSUKI, an upheaval known as Kyoho's direct petition occurred as a result of the Great Famine of Kyoho, and the domain fell into confusion.
Under the fifth lord, Totsuna KUTSUKI, an upheaval known as Kyoho's direct petition occurred as a result of the Great Famine of Kyoho, and the domain fell into confusion.

sen.j: なお、玄綱は明智光秀御霊法会を許可している（御霊祭りの開始）。
sen.e: Totsuna permitted "Goreihokai" (the religious service for the spririt of the dead) for Mitsuhide AKECHI (the beginning of the Goryo Festival).
Note that Totsuna permitted "Goreihokai" (the religious service for the spririt of the dead) for Mitsuhide AKECHI (at the beginning of the Goryo Festival).
sen.cmt: Added "at" in final brackets. Also, I think that "なお" is best as "note that" in this case.
sen.e: Note that Totsuna permitted Goreihokai (the religious service for the spirit of the dead) for Mitsuhide AKECHI (start of the Goryo Festival).
sen.cmt: 原文に『』のない" "を削除at the beginning →startスペル

sen.j: 歴代藩主の中でも第7代藩主・朽木舖綱と第8代藩主・朽木昌綱は文人として知られ、前者は『擬独語』を著わし、藩校創設の基礎を築き上げた。
sen.e: Among the successive lords of the domain, the seventh lord, Nobutsuna KUTSUKI, and the eighth lord, Masatsuna, were known as men of letters, and the former who wrote "Gidokugo" (miscellaneous notes) established the foundation for a domain school.

Among the successive lords of the domain, the seventh lord, Nobutsuna KUTSUKI, and the eighth lord, Masatsuna, were known as men of letters, and the former who wrote "Gidokugo" (miscellaneous notes) established the foundation for a domain school.
sen.cmt: Not sure about translation of "Gidokugo" as "Miscellaneous notes".
sen.e: Among the successive lords of the domain, the seventh lord, Nobutsuna KUTSUKI, and the eighth lord, Masatsuna KUTSUKI, were known as men of letters, and the former who wrote "Gidokugo" (miscellaneous notes) established the foundation for a domain school.

sen.j: 後者は大槻玄沢ら蘭学者やオランダ商館長（カピタン）と交遊を持って蘭学を研究し、『蘭学階梯』の序文や『泰西輿地図説』、『古今泉貨鑑』など、多くの貴重な著作を残した。
sen.e: The latter learned Western studies by associating with scholars of Western studies like Gentaku OTSUKI, and left many valuable books, such as the introduction of "Rangaku-kaitei" (a guide to foreign languages), "Taisei-yochizusetsu" (a foreign topography), and "Kokon-senka-kagami" (a reference book of coins).

The latter learned Western studies by associating with scholars of Western studies like Gentaku OTSUKI, and left many valuable books, such as the introduction of "Rangaku-kaitei" (a guide to foreign languages), "Taisei-yochizusetsu" (a foreign topography), and "Kokon-senka-kagami" (a reference book of coins).

The latter learned Western studies by associating with scholars of Western studies like Gentaku OTSUKI, and left many valuable books, such as the introduction of "Rangaku-kaitei" (a guide to foreign languages), "Taisei-yochizusetsu" (a foreign topography), and "Kokon-senka-kagami" (a reference book of coins).

sen.j: 第9代藩主・朽木倫綱も領民の教化を図って『岩間の水』を著わしている。
sen.e: The ninth lord, Tomotsuna KUTSUKI, also wrote "Iwama no mizu," spring water issuing from among rocks (a moral book) to educate his people.
The ninth lord, Tomotsuna KUTSUKI, also wrote "Iwama no mizu," spring water issuing from among rocks (a moral book) to educate his people.
The ninth lord, Tomotsuna KUTSUKI, also wrote "Iwama no mizu," spring water issuing from among rocks (a moral book) to educate his people.

sen.j: 福知山藩では財政再建の必要性から、藩政改革がいくたびも行なわれたが、その都度に失敗する。
sen.e: As the Fukuchiyama Domain was under the pressure of the financial reconstruction, it made several attempts to reform the administration of the domain, and failed each time.
Under the pressure to rebuild its finances, the lords made several attempts to reform the administration of the domain, but repeatedly failed in their attempts.
Under the pressure to rebuild its finances, the lords made several attempts to reform the administration of the domain, but repeatedly failed in their attempts.

sen.j: それは、百姓による強訴が常に起こったからである。
sen.e: It was because direct petitions were always made by peasants.
The reason for failure was that direct petitions were always made by the peasants.
The reason for failure was that direct petitions were always made by the peasants.

sen.j: 特に前述の享保年間と、幕末の万治元年（1860年）の強訴は大規模であった。
sen.e: Especially, the direct petition in the Kyoho era mentioned above and the one in 1860 at the end of Edo period were large-scale.
The direct petition in the Kyoho era mentioned above and one in 1860 at the end of Edo period were large in scale.
The direct petition in the Kyoho era mentioned above and one in 1860 at the end of Edo period were large in scale.

The chronological order of the Lords.
